title: Top Careers in Computer Science | Careers, Salaries, and Resources

extracted_data.title: Top Careers in Computer Science | Careers, Salaries, and Resources
extracted_data.main_content:
![](https://res.cloudinary.com/highereducation/images/f_auto,q_auto/g_face,c_fill,fl_lossy,q_auto:best,w_448,h_382/v1662131233/ComputerScience.org/CompSci_Careers_FTR_2969cf52f/CompSci_Careers_FTR_2969cf52f.jpg?_i=AA)
Typical duties for workers with information technology (IT) and computer science jobs include developing and supporting computer systems, networks, software, and hardware. High-employing industries for computer science professionals include software publishing, higher education, government agencies, and computer systems design.
Some of the highest-paying and most in-demand computer science roles include software developer, computer and information research scientist, and information security analyst.
Many entry-level jobs in this field require at least a bachelor's degree. Depending on your specific career goal, you may also need a master's degree. However, professionals can also land positions without a computer science degree if they complete a coding bootcamp, teach themselves key skills, or earn relevant computer science professional certifications.
Use our guide to learn more about some of the best careers in computer science, including the different computer science fields of work and how to find a job in this growing space. We describe what to expect from computer science jobs, highlight several prominent employers, and provide helpful resources.
Popular Online Programs
Learn about start dates, transferring credits, availability of financial aid, and more by contacting the universities below.

Computer Science Career | Median Annual Salary, May 2023 |
---|---|

[$120,360](https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes151212.htm)[Database Administrators](/careers/database-administrator/)
[$101,510](https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes151242.htm)[BLS](https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes_stru.htm)

Computer Science Career | Job Outlook, 2022-32 |
---|---|
Information Security Analysts |
|
[+25%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/software-developers.htm)[+23%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-and-information-research-scientists.htm)[Web Developers](/careers/web-developer/)and Digital Designers
[+16%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/web-developers.htm)[Computer Systems Analysts](/careers/systems-analyst/)
[+10%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-systems-analysts.htm)[BLS](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/)
Salary Potential and Career Outlook for Computer Scientists
The [U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/home.htm) (BLS) projects 23% growth for computer science and information technology jobs between 2022 and 2032 — a much-faster-than-average growth rate, which may indicate continued demand for workers with tech skills as society continues to incorporate technology into everyday life.
[BLS data](https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes151299.htm) also reveals computer science and related occupations earn higher-than-average wages: Their median annual salary was $104,920 in May 2023, more than double the median wage of $45,760 for all workers nationwide.
Explore the two charts below for data about some of the highest-paid and fastest-growing [computer science jobs](/resources/best-computer-science-jobs/).
Major Employers of Computer Scientists
-
Microsoft: Founded in 1975 and headquartered in Redmond, Washington, Microsoft is the largest software maker globally. The company employs 221,000 workers worldwide, including 120,000 in the U.S. Microsoft hires tech professionals in roles like software engineer, data scientist, and solution architect. -
Alphabet: Alphabet is the parent company of Google, one of the world's biggest internet product creators and suppliers. To advance its mission to "organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful," Google employs various computer science professionals, including software engineers, UX researchers, and software developers. -
Apple: The company behind the iPhone and Mac computers, Apple is a global juggernaut, reporting a quarterly revenue of $119.6 billion in February 2024. Apple offers computer science jobs in hardware, software and services, and machine learning and AI. -
Amazon: In addition to online shopping, Amazon offers cloud services, hardware devices, entertainment, and delivery and logistics. Computer science professionals can find jobs in software development, software engineering, and data science at Amazon. -
Meta: Originally created in 2004 under the name Facebook, Meta is a tech company that runs social media and communication platforms. They are also developing augmented and virtual reality tools for social experiences. Meta hires computer science professionals for roles like computer research scientist, security software engineer, product designer, and data scientist. -
U.S. Department of Defense: The largest government agency in the U.S., the Department of Defense (DoD), deploys military personnel to help deter war and advance national security. The department develops quick, agile, advanced technology to protect American lives and interests. DoD jobs for people with computer science degrees include cyberthreat analysts, machine learning scientists, and artificial intelligence engineers. -
NIKE, Inc: Globally recognized for its bestselling Nike, Jordan, and Converse brands, NIKE produces top-selling athletic shoes and apparel. The company uses technology to develop products, support design engineers, and harness big data from around the world. Its technology team includes lead Android engineers, cyberdefense analysts, and technical operations specialists.
Note this list is not exhaustive. Other large companies that hire tech workers include Intel, IBM, and Cisco, and many other smaller organizations also employ computer and IT professionals.
Find Your Computer Science Career
[Computer Engineer](https://www.computerscience.org/computer-engineering/careers/computer-engineer/)[Computer Forensics Investigator](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-forensics-investigator/)[Computer Programmer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-programmer/)[Data Scientist](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/data-science/)[Database Administrator](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/database-administrator/)[Full-Stack Developer](https://www.computerscience.org/web-development/careers/full-stack-developer/)[Hardware Engineer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-hardware-engineer/)[Health Information Technician](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/health-information-technician/)[Information Researcher](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-information-researcher/)[Information Security Analyst](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/information-security-analyst/)[Information Technology Architect](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/information-technology-architect/)[Network Administrator](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/network-administrator/)[Software Developer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/software-developer/)[Software Engineer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/software-engineer/)[Systems Analyst](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/systems-analyst/)[Systems Manager](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/systems-manager/)[Video Game Designer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/video-game-designer/)[Web Designer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/web-design/)[Web Developer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/web-developer/)
Popular Online Programs
Learn about start dates, transferring credits, availability of financial aid, and more by contacting the universities below.
Get a Tech Job With a Computer Science Degree
Many careers in computer science — like software developer, information security analyst, and database administrator — typically require a bachelor's [degree in computer science](/degrees/). Entry-level roles for most positions in this field do not require relevant work experience, though completing an internship or maintaining a programming portfolio can help you stand out in the job search.
Some computer science roles, such as computer and information research scientist, require a master's degree. Even if employers do not require a graduate degree, holding an advanced educational credential can help you qualify for upper-level jobs and higher salaries. Some companies may even cover master's program tuition as part of their [education benefits](/resources/companies-that-pay-for-college/).
In some cases, you can qualify for entry-level tech positions after completing a [computer science bootcamp](/bootcamps/resources/bootcamps-vs-degrees/) and/or earning [computer science certifications](/degrees/certifications/computer-science/). Learn about some of the [leading tech companies](/resources/companies-that-dont-require-a-college-degree/) where you can work without earning a computer science degree.
Discover Resources for Working in Computer Science
Professional organizations can help computer science students and career switchers network, find work opportunities, and stay updated on new developments in the field. In addition to the options below, you can join organizations like the [IAENG Society of Software Engineering](https://www.iaeng.org/ISSE.html) or [computer science Meetup groups](https://www.meetup.com/topics/computer-science/).
Help for Computer Science Students
[Association for Computing Machinery](https://www.acm.org/)
The largest computing society in the world, ACM includes 38 special interest groups and 860 local chapters. Members can access publications, conferences, and networking opportunities.
[Computing Research Association](https://cra.org/)
CRA includes 250 member organizations from North America that work on computing research problems. Founded in 1972, the group includes government, research, and academic members.
[IEEE Computer Society](https://www.computer.org/)
This organization helps computer science and engineering professionals in all areas of the field advance in their careers through webinars, conferences, and publications.
[Association for Women in Computing](https://www.awc-hq.org/home.html)
Based in Washington, DC, AWC provides members mentoring, education, service, and networking opportunities through local chapters nationwide.
Help for Career Switchers
[CompTIA Career Change](https://www.comptia.org/career-change)
CompTIA offers professional tech certifications and training to help you launch or advance your computer science career.
[Learn to Code with Me](https://learntocodewith.me/posts/career-change-at-40/)
This organization offers advice for learning computer science and shifting into tech careers.
[edX](https://www.edx.org/)
An online learning platform, edX offers free or affordable courses, certificates, and micro-master's programs in various tech-related fields.
[InfoSec Institute](https://www.infosecinstitute.com/)
This organization provides technical training, certifications, and self-paced learning programs to prepare people without computer science degrees for tech jobs.
FAQ About Computer Science Degrees and Jobs
Do you need a computer science degree to get a job in tech?
If you earn a computer science degree, you can qualify for an array of entry-level tech jobs like computer programmer, software developer, and database administrator. However, you may also land tech roles without a degree by completing a bootcamp, earning a professional certification, or building a portfolio that highlights your relevant knowledge and skills.
What jobs can you get with a computer science degree?
Which tech careers you qualify for depends on your education level, prior work experience, and employer. However, a computer science degree can help prepare you for various occupations, including information security analyst, computer systems analyst, computer and information research scientist, and network and computer systems administrator.
Do computer science degrees increase job stability and salary potential?
In general, the more education you have, the higher your salary and the greater your job stability. In 2023, the [National Center for Education Statistics](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/coe/indicator/cba/annual-earnings) reported that full-time workers aged 25-34 with a bachelor's degree earned an annual average of $61,600 compared to $74,600 for same-age workers with a master's degree.
Are computer jobs going away because of AI?
We cannot be certain about how AI will impact computer jobs in the future. Though AI can generate code for computer programming or analyze data, [some industry experts predict](https://www.businessinsider.com/chatgpt-jobs-at-risk-replacement-artificial-intelligence-ai-labor-trends-2023-02) that AI will actually augment tech professionals' work to be more efficient rather than replace them.
Last reviewed June 21, 2023.
